en.text:
Alright‚Ä¶ I just found out this girl DOESN‚ÄôT EXIST üò≥
She‚Äôs 100% AI-generated.

And she has more followers than me.

It‚Äôs getting harder and harder to tell whether a photo is real or not. Be careful about idealizing everything you see on social media, because there might not even be a real person behind it.

Recommendation algorithms analyze much more than just your likes.

They measure how long you look at something, whether you pause a video, scroll back, zoom in on an image‚Ä¶ even what you ignore.

With all of that, they build a predictive profile of your interests.

They don‚Äôt show you what‚Äôs most true.
They show you what‚Äôs most likely to keep you there.

And that completely changes how we consume information.

Many people think that when an AI gives an incorrect answer, it‚Äôs because it‚Äôs ‚Äúlying.‚Äù But that‚Äôs not really how it works.

Language models don‚Äôt search for the truth ‚Äî they search for the most probable next word based on the data they were trained on. If they don‚Äôt have enough information or the topic is very specific, they can generate details that sound completely convincing.

This is called a ‚Äúhallucination.‚Äù
It‚Äôs not malice. It‚Äôs statistics.

So using AI is fine ‚Äî but trusting it blindly isn‚Äôt.

A bot isn‚Äôt always obvious. It‚Äôs not just an account with a weird username and zero photos.

It can be designed to look completely human: posting memes, commenting on news, interacting with other users.

If hundreds of bots support the same idea, it can create the illusion of real consensus.

And when we believe that ‚Äúeveryone thinks this way,‚Äù we‚Äôre much less likely to question it.

That‚Äôs where the real problem begins.

es.text:

Y tiene m√°s seguidores que yo.

Cada vez es m√°s dif√≠cil saber si una foto es real o no. Ojo con idealizar todo lo que ves en redes, porque puede que ni siquiera haya una persona detr√°s.

Los algoritmos de recomendaci√≥n analizan much√≠simo m√°s que tus likes.

Miden cu√°nto tiempo te quedas mirando algo, si haces pausa en un v√≠deo, si vuelves atr√°s, si ampl√≠as una imagen‚Ä¶ incluso lo que ignoras.

Con todo eso crean un perfil predictivo de tus intereses.

No te ense√±an lo m√°s verdadero.
Te ense√±an lo m√°s probable que te haga quedarte.

Y eso cambia completamente c√≥mo consumimos informaci√≥n.

Mucha gente piensa que cuando una IA da una respuesta incorrecta es porque ‚Äúmiente‚Äù. Pero en realidad no funciona as√≠.

Los modelos de lenguaje no buscan la verdad, buscan la palabra m√°s probable seg√∫n los datos con los que fueron entrenados. Si no tienen suficiente informaci√≥n o el tema es muy espec√≠fico, pueden inventar detalles que suenan completamente convincentes.

A eso se le llama ‚Äúalucinaci√≥n‚Äù.
No es malicia. Es estad√≠stica.

Por eso usar IA est√° bien, pero confiar ciegamente no.

Un bot no siempre es obvio. No es una cuenta con nombre raro y cero fotos.

Puede estar dise√±ado para parecer totalmente humano: publica memes, comenta noticias, interact√∫a con otros usuarios.

Si cientos de bots apoyan una misma idea, puede parecer que hay un consenso real.

Y cuando creemos que ‚Äútodo el mundo piensa as√≠‚Äù, tendemos a cuestionarlo menos.

Ah√≠ est√° la clave del problema.
